page.title: 18THE SAMLESBURY WITCHES
page.content: In August 1612, the most famous witch trials in English history were held at Lancaster Castle and involved seven residents of Samlesbury. The alleged victim, Grace Sowerbutts, testified that her grandmother, Aunt Ellen and Jane Southworth had bewitched her and also a very young child, whose parents lived at The Boathouse.The baby died and soon after its burial in the church yard, the withes were supposed to have exhumed the body and cooked it.However, the judges realised that Grace was committing perjury and as a result of sharp questioning, she admitted that the Rev. Christopher Southworth had put her up to it. The priest might have been taking revenge on his relative for becoming a Protestant. So the innocent people of Samlesbury were aquitted, but others from Pendle were condemned to death.
